text: today on Applied Science I want to show
you a really unusual phenomenon that I
haven't seen demonstrated before I
recently picked up this high pulse power
laser on eBay and what do you do when
you get a high-power laser you start
aiming at stuff and burning things and
so one of the things nearby on my desk
was the receipt that the eBay seller
packed into the box and this laser is
coupled into a fiber here so when we
turn it on the laser light comes out the
end of this fiber and I just started
rolling it along the piece of paper and
saw that it was leaving a little trail
of burn marks behind and I thought oh
that's cool it's burning the paper but
then a few minutes later the burn marks
were gone and I thought I must have just
forgot you know the exact spot that I
was burning and so I kind of started
investigating a little bit closer and
realized that this technique would
actually make marks on the paper that
reliably disappeared exactly four
minutes after they were created and I
thought how weird is that I mean this is
not expected it seems like there might
even be potentially some commercial
applications to this so I kind of
started poking into it a bit more and
realize that the chemical that's causing
this to happen
are these whitening agents that they put
into paper these are fluorescent
additives to make the paper look whiter
than white basically and in the course

across the spark gap and every time it
does this we get a pulse of laser light
out and the neat thing is that the
pulses are very short so all that energy
that was stored up in the capacitor sort
of comes out all at once and the sticker
here claims that the peak power can be

so the kinds of tricks you can play with
